subject: CBS Evening News with Katie Couric E-Mail Alert
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Good afternoon. This is Harry Smith filling in for
  Katie.
 
It’s a state of emergency in part of Northern California, where thousands of acres of
  woodlands have been burned, and hundreds of homes have been destroyed in a
  massive forest fire. The blaze, near Lake Tahoe,
  is heading straight toward another residential area. Bill Whitaker will be
  live with the latest.
 
Turning our attention to Iraq,
  a suicide bomber penetrated layers of security in a highly guarded Baghdad hotel before
  blowing himself up in lobby. The blast killed four tribal leaders and eight
  others – it was apparently targeting a meeting of U.S.-allied Sunni
  leaders. Our chief foreign correspondent Lara Logan reports from the scene.
 
Many call the 9/11 aftermath an environmental
  disaster. Former EPA administrator, Christie Todd Whitman faced questioning today
  on Capitol Hill over her reaction to the attack. National Correspondent Byron
  Pitts will report.
 
Also in Washington,
  new rulings by the Supreme Court are exposing its political colors since
  President Bush’s appointees joined the bench. Call it the Roberts and
  Alito factor. Wyatt Andrews will have the story.
 
In health news, more doctors are asking mothers if
  they’d like to save their baby’s umbilical cord blood – and
  more mothers are doing it. The blood is rich in stem cells that can be used
  to treat certain diseases later in life. Dr. Jon LaPook will have the story.
 
Also tonight, Tracy Smith will have a follow-up of
  the Iraqi orphan story Lara Logan broke on the CBS Evening News last week.
  Smith will talk to the wife of one of the soldiers about why his role in the
  rescue effort meant so much to her personally.
 
Finally, what would you do to get into the next
  restaurant hotspot? Wait in line? Max out your credit card? Go behind bars?
  If the latter seems unreasonable, you probably haven’t heard of the new
  Italian dinner spot, where you can eat alongside convicted murderers and
  mobsters. Allen Pizzey will take you inside for a meal you can’t
  refuse.
 
See you tonight, 
 




Harry Smith
CouricandCo@cbs.com
